abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Recent genetic sequencing studies in large series’ of predominantly childhood medulloblastoma have implicated loss-of-function, predominantly truncating, variants in the <jats:italic>ELP1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>GPR161</jats:italic> genes in causation of the MB<jats:sub>SHH</jats:sub> subtype specifically. The latter association, along with a report of an index case with some features of Gorlin syndrome has led to speculation that <jats:italic>GPR161</jats:italic> may also cause Gorlin syndrome. We show that these genes are associated with relatively low absolute risks of medulloblastoma from extrapolating lifetime risks in the general population and odds ratios from the population database gnomAD. The projected risks are around 1 in 270–430 for <jats:italic>ELP1</jats:italic> and 1 in 1600–2500 for <jats:italic>GPR161.</jats:italic> These risks do not suggest the need for MRI screening in infants with <jats:italic>ELP1</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>GPR161</jats:italic> variants as this is not currently recommended for <jats:italic>PTCH1</jats:italic> where the risks are equivalent or higher. We also screened 27 <jats:italic>PTCH1/SUFU</jats:italic> pathogenic variant-negative patients with Gorlin syndrome for <jats:italic>GPR161</jats:italic> and found no suspicious variants. Given the population frequencies of 0.0962% for <jats:italic>GPR161</jats:italic> and 0.0687% for <jats:italic>ELP1</jats:italic>, neither of these genes can be a cause of Gorlin syndrome with an unexplained population frequency far lower at 0.0021%.</jats:p>

title: Perspectives on the implications of carrying putative pathogenic variants in the medulloblastoma predisposition genes ELP1 and GPR161
